Tell the teacher — but do it politely and as a question, not an accusation.

Quick facts you can use as evidence
- Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System by both diameter (~139,820 km) and mass (~318 times Earth’s mass).  
- Neptune’s diameter (~49,244 km) and mass (~17 times Earth’s mass) are much smaller.

What to check first
- Read the worksheet wording exactly. Sometimes a question can be about a specific category (e.g., “largest terrestrial planet” or “largest of the ice giants”) that would change the answer.
- If it’s simply “largest planet,” the worksheet is wrong.

How to raise it politely
- Email or talk to the teacher calmly and ask for clarification rather than accuse them of a mistake. Example lines:
  - “Hi [Name], on the worksheet dated [date] there’s a question that seems to say Neptune is the largest planet. I thought Jupiter was the largest — could you confirm what the intended answer was?”
  - If your child wants to ask in class: “I learned Jupiter is the biggest planet. Is this question asking something different?”

Why this is a good idea
- Teachers appreciate corrections done respectfully; it’s a teachable moment for the class and helps prevent spreading incorrect facts.
- You can use it to show your child how to check reliable sources (e.g., NASA, Britannica) and how to ask questions respectfully.

If it’s a tiny, ungraded worksheet and you don’t want to make a fuss, letting it go is fine — but correcting factual errors politely is usually helpful.
